Dataframe¶

harrison_functions.utils.std.dataframe.append_standard_df(df, columns)¶
Forces a df to have the select_columns
If it doesn’t fills a column of NA’s

harrison_functions.utils.std.dataframe.execute_query_on_df(dataframe, query, index_name=None, index_list=None)¶

Convenience function


harrison_functions.utils.std.dataframe.sort_df(df, col: list, row: list)¶

harrison_functions.utils.std.dataframe.split_df(df, x, c=None)¶
Helper function for plot_multiple_scatter and plot_violin
Takes a dataframe in the following format:

cat

val

cat_1

val_1.1

cat_1

val_1.2

…

cat_2

val_2.1

cat_2

val_2.2

…
If you instead have:

cat1

cat2

…

val_1.1

val_2.1

…

val_1.2

val_2.2

…
Reshape it into the appropriate format using pd.melt
pd.melt(df, value_vars = [cat1, cat2, …], var_name=’category’)
The order of the value_vars determines the order they appear on the plot.

harrison_functions.utils.std.dataframe.random_resample(df, category_col, input_sampling_lim)¶
Takes a df with numerical columns and a category column
Returns a df that has been randomly undersampled
Example input:

conc

vol

error

0

101.41532

169.6

“None”

1

46.85500

167.2

“Clot Error”
Example sampling limit dictionary
sampling_lims = {'None': 100,
                 'Clot Error': 100,
                 ... }
Note: should probably rewrite this function using the random module, but this works for now

harrison_functions.utils.std.dataframe.count_outcome_pass_fail(df)¶
Given a df with the following:

id

val_1

outcome_1

val_2

outcome_2

…

1

true

Pass

619

Pass

…

2

false

Fail

222

Pass

…

Counts number of Pass or Fail per row and returns them as extra columns

Returns:

id

…

total_pass

total_fail

1

…

2

10

2

…

11

1

harrison_functions.utils.std.dataframe.col_to_list(df, index, col, is_dict=False)¶
Takes a dataframe like the following:

index

col_name

1

1

1

2

2

3

2

3 # duplicate row

2

4
and returns the following:

index

col

1

[1, 2]

2

[3, 4]
Note: list items are unique

harrison_functions.utils.std.dataframe.list_to_col(df, list_col: str)¶
Takes a dataframe like the following:

idx

list_col

1

[1, 2]

2

[3, 4, 5]
and returns the following:

idx

list_col

1

1

1

2

2

3

2

4

2

5

harrison_functions.utils.std.dataframe.dict_to_col(df, col: str, to_include=False, prefix=None)¶
Expands a single dataframe column containing dictionaries into columns.
Input:

idx_1

…

new_cols

idx_1

…

{‘key_1’: val_1, ‘key_2’: val_2, …}
Returns:

idx_0

…

key_1

key_2

…

val_0

…

val_1

val_2

…
This does not work well with 500K rows.
If there are too many rows, break the df into chunks:
new_df = pd.DataFrame()
step = 1000
for i in tqdm(range(100)):
    new_df = pd.concat([new_df, dict_to_col(df[step*i:step*(i+1)], 'dict')])

harrison_functions.utils.std.dataframe.cols_to_dict(df, cols: list, col_name='dict_col', to_include=False)¶
Collapses columns into a single column containing dictionaries.
Input:

idx_0

…

key_1

key_2

…

val_0

…

val_1

val_2

…
Returns:

idx_1

…

new_col

idx_1

…

{“key_1”: val_1, “key_2”: val_2, …}

harrison_functions.utils.std.dataframe.expand_col(df, cols: list, to_include=False, to_append_name=False)¶

Applies dict_to_col on multiple columns


harrison_functions.utils.std.dataframe.get_unique_list_items(df_list_col)¶
Given a dataframe column with a list, returns all the categories in that list.

idx

df_list_col

0

[val_1, val_2]

1

[val_2, val_3, val_4]
Returns:
[val_1, val_2, val_3, val_4, ...]

harrison_functions.utils.std.dataframe.generate_histogram_table(df, bins: list, value: float, category: str)¶
Takes a df with the following columns:

category

value

cat_1

6

cat_2

12

…

…
and a list of bins: bins = [0, 10, 20, ...]
And returns a table with the following columns:

value_bins

cat_1

cat_2

…

[0, 10)

1

0

…

[10, 20)

0

1

…

…

…

…

…
Used to convert the input for plot_violin to the input for plot_panel_histogram

harrison_functions.utils.std.dataframe.create_agg_table(df, group, agg, col_order=None, row_order=None)¶

Shortcut for groupby


harrison_functions.utils.std.dataframe.make_sankey_df(history_df, dropna=False, fillna='None')¶
Counts the number of occurences of each line of the history_df
Takes a history_df in this format:

idx

0

1

…

id_1

cat_1

cat_2

…

id_2

cat_2

None

…
Returns:

0

1

…

num

idx_0

idx_1

…

1

cat_1

cat_2

…

2

1

8

…

2

cat_2

None

…

10

2

9

…
use history_df.pivot to get the history_df after indexing
history_df = history_df.pivot(index='rq', columns='ib_num', values='specimen_type')

harrison_functions.utils.std.dataframe.make_link_and_node_df(sankey_df, num_steps: int, dropna=False)¶
Takes a df in the following format (output of make_sankey_df):

0

1

…

num

step_0

step_1

…

1

cat_1

cat_2

…

2

0

8

…

2

cat_2

None

…

10

1

9

…
Returns link_df:

source

target

num

0

0

8

114

1

1

9

57
Returns node_df:

source

label

step

0

0

cat_1

step_0

1

1

cat_2

step_0

harrison_functions.utils.std.dataframe.bag_to_df(bag, flatten=None, take=10000)¶
Converts bag to dataframe
Make sure the take value is high enough but not too high
